comments.body:
```suggestion
    choices: Sequence[ArrayLike],
```
I think it's important to emphasize that this input is _not_ an array, as it means shapes like `(0, 3)` are not handled sensibly.
Same for the other overload

The tricky part is that, without proper shape support, expressing this will be either very difficult and/or verbose. 
For example even `Sequence[ArrayLike]` does not include the likes of `np.ndarray` or `pd.DataFrane`, both of which are (strictly speaking) not proper sequences.

comments.body:
I am assuming we are allowing number subtypes for one but not the other why is that ?
In other words, why is there a difference in return types of the above two overloads ?

The key difference is that the first one is a `TypeVar` while the latter is not.

To illustrate, in the first overload an arbitrary `number` subclass (denoted by `_Number`) 
is provided as input and a value of the same type is returned.

In the second overload we know that an instance of `np.int_` is returned, 
but there is a catch: `np.int_` is a platform-dependent alias for one of the `number` subclasses, 
which is not something we've been able to easily express as of yet.

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/92665ab229a2426db33bcfaa65cd73493acbad95/numpy/__init__.pyi#L511-L517

As a workaround the latter case is now simply annotated as returning _a_ `number` instance and
while correct, this is obviously not as specific as it could be.
okay got it, if my understanding is correct, the functionality is exactly the same if we use number of _Number here (second overload), but it is something we want to change in the future ?

> ..., but it is something we want to change in the future ?

~Correct, once we've dealt with these platform-dependent `generic` subclasses.~

Oh hang on, I'm actually confusing the issues pertaining `int_` and `number` here, sorry.

The problem with returning`number` is more straightforward.
As `ArrayLike` is not yet `Generic` with respect to the data type we don't have a way yet to correlate the input and output types. 
In the future we should be able to use expressions such as the one below (or at least something similar):
```python
>>> from typing import TypeVar
>>> import numpy as np
>>> from numpy.typing import ArrayLike

>>> T = TypeVar('T', bound=np.number)

>>> def func(a: ArrayLike[T]) -> T:
...     pass

```

If you're interested, see https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/16759 for more details.
should dtype also be optional since dtype=None is also valid ?

As `None` is a valid argument for `np.dtype` it is already included in the union defining `DtypeLike`:

``` python
In [1]: import numpy as np                                                                    

In [2]: np.dtype(None)                                                                        
Out[2]: dtype('float64')
```

Yep thats true, not sure I can explain the below:
```
reveal_type(np.prod(d, dtype=None))
```
errors out as

error: No overload variant of "prod" matches argument types "ndarray", "None". Maybe also worth adding it to the tests.

> error: No overload variant of "prod" matches argument types "ndarray", "None".

Odd, are you sure you've got the correct branch checked out?
I can't seem to reproduce the issue over here:
``` python
import numpy as np      

a = np.array(1)
b = np.prod(a, dtype=None)

reveal_type(b)
```

``` shell
>>> mypy ./test.py
test.py:6: note: Revealed type is 'numpy.number'
```
oops, yes it was something to do with my env (had a modified test elsewhere). thanks for the clarification.

Also an option. At least this narrows it down to the particular `signedinteger` subclasses.
This actually doesnâ€™t work-I did it the way it is on purpose. `__new__` is special in that it _must_ return a subclass, which the union is not.
Hm, that's a shame. Ah well, `dtype` it is.

```suggestion
        dtype: Union[str, _SupportsDtype],
```
There are many kind of literal string were we can't statically infer the dtype.

Most notably among them are `"S<x>"`- and `"U<x>"`-based strings (with `<x>` being an integer) for `np.bytes_` and `np.str_`.
That should more likely be covered in `_SupportsDtype` than here.

Could you ellaborate? 
`_SupportsDtype` describes objects with `dtype` attribute so I don't see how this includes builtin strings such as `"S<x>"`.

Oops meant to say `_DtypeLike`, but I have of course removed that overload.

So yes, a `str` overload is needed, not sure that is should be a part of this overload though because we can make `_SupportsDtype` work better by making it generic over dtype.

comments.body: Aren't these properties of `np.number` anyway?

~~They are and they were already defined for `np.number` some time ago~~

Hang on, for some reason this `_real_generic` mixing is subclassed in a number of `np.number` sub-classes but not `np.number` itself. This doesn't seem right.

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/32b3f82e4862d85c5aebba2b2b82a931038cd103/numpy/__init__.pyi#L381-L387

What makes `np.complexfloating` somewhat unique is that the return type of 
`.real` and `.imag` is not `type(self)`; it's one of the `np.floating` subclasses.
I think we forgot that integers support real and imag too, to match python

> I think we forgot that integers support real and imag too, to match python

I think we're safe here actually, as `_real_generic` is included in the definition of `integer`:

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/32b3f82e4862d85c5aebba2b2b82a931038cd103/numpy/__init__.pyi#L407

Still, it would in my opinion be cleaner to just move `real` and `imag` to the `np.generic` superclass.
As both properties have to be redefined for `np.complexfloating` anyway (due to their distinct return type) 
the original concern should not be an issue (https://github.com/numpy/numpy-stubs/pull/14#discussion_r175656159).
I think number makes more sense than generic, as the result of str_.real is nonsense

That might for the better, yes.
I had to double check but `real` and `imag` will apparently be deprecated for non-numeric types anyway (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/10818).

In any case, I'm planning to save this for a future maintenance pull request as there are also a few other issues I'd like to fix in one go (_e.g._ `str` and `bytes` are missing from a couple of `__init__()`s).

@@ -1,1 +470,474 @@    def real(self) -> _FloatType: ...
    @property

comments.body: Why is `ignore` needed here but not on the others?

`__abs__()` is already defined a super-class while the other two are not (as per our previous `real`/`imag` discussion):

https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/32b3f82e4862d85c5aebba2b2b82a931038cd103/numpy/__init__.pyi#L256

Mypy will complain due to incompatibilities between the super- and sub-types' signatures, 
complaints which are silenced by `# type: ignore[override]`.

For more details: https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/common_issues.html#incompatible-overrides

comments.body:
To summarize the various overloads:
1. Overload for filtering out any `str`/`bytes`-based array-likes. This is needed as `bytes` would otherwise be recognized as a `Sequence[int]` sub-type (which is bad) and `str` would otherwise be caught by overload 6. (as `str` is a sequence of strings, which is a sequence of strings, _etc._).
2. Number-based overload
3. Timedelta-based overload
4. Datetime-based overload
5. Object-based overload. `other` is typed as `Any` here as object arrays can be extremely flexible (depending on the actual underlying objects).
6. A final overload to handle all sequences whose nesting level is too deep for the previous overloads.

I'm not 100% sure if all these dunders are considered public or not (especially the bottom three). Are there any about annotating them?

Secondly, they could be marked with `Final` if they should be considered read-only.
`__path__` is a python builtin that's added to all packages, like `__name__`.

The annoying thing it is not defined for [`types.ModuleType`](https://github.com/python/typeshed/blob/a1a51f5aace0989301576c7f7edc7432bef6f5c9/stdlib/3/_importlib_modulespec.pyi#L35-L42) (as not all modules are packages), and by extension for `numpy`.
This is arguably an issue that should be solved in mypy though (or perhaps even typeshed).

How about the likes of `np.__NUMPY_SETUP__`, `np.__deprecated_attrs__` and `np.__expired_functions__` though?
They're not (clearly) marked as private, but I'm not 100% sure whether or they're considered public.
I would consider them private, maybe they should never have been a dunder as such.  I am least sure about `__NUMPY_SETUP__`, but frankly, I wonder if that will matter in a typing context.

Yeah, for now I've just removed them (https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/18229/commits/7060d5e28f735199df6b465755ddd1d3bc7ed07e).
We can always consider revisiting this subject if the need arises.

comments.body: The double leading underscore is used for denoting position-only arguments per [PEP 484](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/#positional-only-arguments). The newer `/`-based syntax introduced in [PEP 570](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0570/) is, unfortunatelly, not yet supported by mypy for python versions prior to python 3.8.

comments.body:
There are a couple of cases where the return-type is dependant on the unit (`datetime64` and `timedelta64`) or some other underlying object (`void` and `object_`). 
In the long term, it might be worthwhile to make these classes [generic](https://docs.python.org/dev/glossary.html#term-generic-type) w.r.t. a suitable parameter (_e.g._ the unit) to sort this out.

It might be worthwhile to add support for the `__fspath__` protocol at some point, 
so one can also pass the likes of `pathlib.Path`.

dtype-support is, for now, limited to dtype-likes that can be parametrized w.r.t. `np.generic`. 
For all others the dtype will be set to `Any`.

Unfortunately we can't express the return of an `ndarray`-subclass with a specific dtype 
(_e.g._ `ndarray[float64] -> matrix[int64]`). This would require higher-kinded TypeVars, which we don't have.

comments.body:
Multiplying a fixed-size dtype with 1 currently issues a `FutureWarning` and returns the passed dtype unaltered.
Out of curiosity, how long has this warning been in place and when is the switch to this new behavior planned?

``` python
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: dtype_i8 = np.dtype(np.int64)
   ...: dtype_i8 * 1
<ipython-input-2-b3084159de63>:2: FutureWarning: Passing (type, 1) or '1type' as a synonym of type is deprecated; in a future version of numpy, it will be understood as (type, (1,)) / '(1,)type'.
  dtype_i8 * 1
Out[2]: dtype('int64')
```
